newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares' rise to be short-lived.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares' rise to be short-lived.

text.p: Leading Russian shares rose on Thursday on news President Boris Yeltsin had returned to work to Moscow and progress in Chechnya talks, traders said.
They said they did not expect the rise to continue in the next few days.
The Russian Trading System index of 21 leading shares rose by 2.84 percent to 180.87.

"In the morning the reports came that (General Alexander) Lebed cancelled bombing and Yeltsin returned to Moscow and was working. It gave a spur to the market," said Alexander Bobolev, a trader from IK Aton.
Russian television showed a brief clip of Yeltsin laughing and smiling as he spoke with new health minister Tatyana Dmitriyeva.
Talks between Lebed and Chechen separatist leaders were going well and the two sides were working out a detailed schedule on how to stop the war, Lebed said on Thursday.
But Yuri Agaronik, chief analyst from IK Prospekt, said charts were not pointing to a continuing advance in shares.
"By technical analysis, we do not see any preconditions for the (falling) trend to change," he said.
Agaronik said the decision by the International Monetary Fund to give Russia the delayed July tranche of its 10 billion loan had given another push up to the prices.
Prices rose on the political news in early trade, but sank later, only to recover in the evening, traders said.

"I think brokers were pushing up prices in speculative buying on the news about granting the credit and the improvement of the situation in Chechnya," Agaronik said. "If there are more orders they will meet higher prices."
Mosenergo closed at $0.96 after $0.95 at Wednesday's close, LUKoil rose to $9.85 from $9.40, Norilsk Nickel edged up to $7.85 from $7.50 and UES was $0.0804 after $0.0765.
